awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Disruptive Semiconductor Software Tool for Recipe Optimization for Deposition and Etching Processes
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project is the enablement of next generation manufacturing technologies for semiconductor devices. The deployment of novel semiconductor devices such as 3D NAND, the latest device architecture developed for flash memory, is often stymied by the development of nanomanufacturing processes. The objective of this proposal is to build upon a recipe prediction platform to create a standalone software solution for semiconductor equipment and chip manufacturers to rapidly optimize their processes.  In this research, the software speed will be increased, prediction capabilities will be extended to 3D structures, and model calibration will be automated to facilitate customer deployment. By accelerating the development of the processes used in device fabrication, this project reduces the cost of recipe development in the semiconductor industry and bringing next-generation technologies to fruition.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project will develop new advanced physical and statistical models to quickly and accurately predict outcomes for processes like plasma etch and deposition. In this research, 2D and 3D profile simulations will be algorithmically optimized for speed to give process engineers instantaneous results. Machine learning models will be used to enable process engineers to rapidly explore complex trade spaces. Sophisticated numerical algorithms will be developed to help engineers maximize process windows. Innovations in statistical and physics-based tools will permit process engineers to build and calibrate models themselves, enabling next-generation technologies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Reducing process development time and accelerating time to market are perennial challenges in semiconductor manufacturing. For etch and deposition processes in particular, engineers must navigate large, multi-dimensional, and nonlinear parameter spaces to find a stable process window that meets their recipe targets. Today, this optimization is still largely done by an iterative trial and error approach or simplistic statistical models and requires companies to invest heavily in development and recipe scaling to meet increasingly stringent manufacturing requirements. The development of computational models that predict process outcomes across the wafer would enable manufacturers to optimize process design flows and predict process defects before a single wafer is even run. In this SBIR research, SandBox Semiconductor developed a commercial software to automate etch and deposition recipe development. The developed software, SandBox Studio AI, uses physics-based models calibrated with experiments to provide engineers with a convenient means to explore process parameter spaces and uncover the recipe that meets the targeted ranges of critical dimensions for the process. 

Using SandBox Studio AI, process engineers can:

  • Store and curate large volumes of multi-modal data types in an easy-to-use interface
  • Automatically build a physics-based model using a limited set of experimental data
  • Rapidly analyze process trends and sensitivities using customized visualization tools
  • Identify optimal recipe windows in multi-dimensional parameter spaces
  • Virtually manipulate and optimize different recipe configurations
  • Perform 2D and 3D feature scale recipe optimizations
  • Perform 2D across wafer optimizations

Semiconductors are critical to the United States economic and national security. With the support of this Phase II grant, SandBox is helping the United States regain its leadership in semiconductor research and development. The innovations of this SBIR research have already helped major semiconductor manufacturers improve process yield, increase process quality, and reduce development costs.

Over the course of this SBIR research, SandBox employed three part-time undergraduate interns from the University of Texas at Austin and one high school student.

 


Last Modified: 08/01/2023
Modified by: Meghali J Chopra
